1. Introduction to Quantum Mechanics. Wave Function

Subject and methods of quantum mechanics.
Experimental and theoretical prerequisites for the development of quantum mechanics.
Necessity of probabilistic and statistical interpretation of de Broglie waves.
Wave function. Probability density. Normalization condition. General requirements for the wave function.

Parity. Parity conservation law.
Equations of motion in quantum mechanics. Ehrenfest theorem. Bohr correspondence principle.

title: Phase-Field Simulator for Microstructure Evolution in Zr-Nb-Sn Alloys
text:
\(\leftarrow\) Return to the projects list


Phase-Field Simulator for Microstructure Evolution in Zr-Nb-Sn Alloys




Main dashboard showing simulation modules and real-time system resource monitoring.

Phase-Field Multistage Simulator is a console-based (TUI) software package I developed for modeling microstructure evolution in multi-component zirconium-based alloys (Zr-Nb-Sn, Zr-Nb, Zr-Sn and related systems) using the phase-field method.
The simulator covers the three key life-cycle stages of structural and functional materials under extreme conditions:

Crystal preparation (annealing, precipitation of secondary phases)
Crystal irradiation (radiation damage accumulation, solute redistribution, phase transformations)
Crystal deformation (plastic flow, strain localization, radiation-modified mechanical behavior)


Key Features

Full 3D phase-field modeling (default dimension = 3)
Highly configurable simulation parameters:

computational grid size (up to \(64 \times 64 \times 64\) and beyond)
alloying element concentrations (Nb, Sn in Zr matrix, 0-10 at.%)
annealing and target temperatures (in Kelvin)
time scales: annealing time, total simulation time, integration timestep, field saving interval, averaging timestep
precipitation level control, balance type

Three independent input modules:

Preparation_input \(\rightarrow\) precipitation of Nb\(_3\)Sn-like phases, \(\beta \rightarrow \alpha\) transformation, coarsening
Irradiation_input \(\rightarrow\) radiation-induced damage, concentration shifts, dose rate, damage/recovery kinetics
Deformation_input \(\rightarrow\) mechanical deformation with inherited irradiation defects, strain rate, deformation mode

Parallel task execution (up to 64 simultaneous tasks, multi-threading / multi-core support)
Built-in CPU usage monitoring, project/task/VTK file lists
Export of field data to .vtk format (compatible with ParaView / OVITO) – concentration fields, phase fields, stress/strain, defect densities



Typical Applications

Simulation of secondary phase precipitation and growth (\(\beta\)-Nb, Zr\(_2\)(Nb,Sn), Laves phases) during heat treatment of Zr-Nb-Sn alloys
Prediction of neutron irradiation effects: solute redistribution, solid solution decomposition, void/cavity formation
Investigation of radiation hardening/softening, irradiation-induced growth (IIG), creep modification
Modeling of deformation behavior in irradiated materials (strain localization, dislocation channeling)
Support for optimization of cladding materials for nuclear reactors and Nb\(_3\)Sn-based superconducting strands/wires (internal oxidation with Zr addition)



Technology Stack

Core language: Perl / C with MPI / OpenMP for parallelism
User interface: text-based (TUI) using ncurses-like library
Result visualization: .vtk export → ParaView
Database backend: SQLite (stores projects, users, task history, input parameters)
Target platform: Linux (server or workstation)



Project Status
Ongoing development includes: - stronger coupling between irradiation and deformation stages - temperature-dependent mobilities and elastic energy contributions - new physical modules (e.g., cascade damage, hydrogen effects)
The simulator is used for: - fundamental studies of microstructure evolution in nuclear Zr alloys - lifetime prediction of reactor components under irradiation - design of advanced heat-treatment and alloying strategies for improved radiation resistance
If you are interested in collaboration, scientific applications – feel free to contact me .

title: Multiscale simulation of X-ray diffraction based on Fresnel–Kirchhoff diffraction theory
text:
\(\leftarrow\) Return to the projects list


Multiscale simulation of X-ray diffraction based on Fresnel–Kirchhoff diffraction theory




Main dashboard showing simulation modules and real-time system resource monitoring.

X-rayDMS is a custom-developed software system for numerical simulation of X-ray diffraction on objects of arbitrary geometry and complexity using the Fresnel–Kirchhoff diffraction approach.

Key Features

Diffraction modeling for simple geometric bodies (sphere, cylinder, ellipsoid, etc.) and complex composite objects
Flexible representation of complex objects via multiple components:

selective component IDs
per-component scaling, rotations (\(\alpha\), \(\beta\), \(\gamma\)), translations (x, y, z) and phase shift \(\Delta\)

Highly configurable source parameters:

wavelength \(\lambda\)
degree of monochromaticity
source size and sampling points
wavefront rotations

Multiple calculation modes:

FAST CALCULATION
SIMPLE OBJECTS
COMPLEX OBJECTS – full multi-component simulation with Monte-Carlo-style sampling options

Computation of both amplitude-phase field and intensity distribution in the detector plane
Web-based project management interface:

project creation and editing
real-time CPU / RAM usage monitoring
execution history
detailed per-task reports
visualization: 2D/3D intensity maps, polar plots, phase & amplitude line profiles




Typical application areas

Analysis of diffraction patterns from nano- and micro-particles
Simulation of SAXS / WAXS patterns for biological and synthetic objects
Evaluation of source coherence and spectral bandwidth effects
Comparison between theoretical predictions and experimental data
Pre-experiment planning (optimization of geometry, wavelength, beam size, etc.)



Technology stack

Core language: Python
Numerical libraries: NumPy, SciPy
Parallel execution: multi-threading / multi-core processing
Web interface: Flask / FastAPI + modern frontend techniques (HTMX / Alpine.js or similar)
Server resources (typical): 8 cores, ~16 GB RAM



Project status
Actively developed.
Regular updates include new object types, calculation speed improvements, and extended result visualization capabilities.
If you are interested in collaboration, scientific applications – feel free to contact me .

title: Yurii M. Ovcharenko
text:
Hello! My name is Yurii Ovcharenko, I am a teacher of physics and researcher in the field of computer modeling of physical processes in metal alloys used in nuclear reactors.
Currently, I work as a senior researcher at the Institute of Applied Physics of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, which is a leading scientific center for applied and fundamental problems of the application of nuclear technologies in the study of the structure and composition of matter. I am a teacher of the discipline Molecular Dynamics and Ab Initio Modeling in Materials Science for graduate students of the institute.
Previously, I was an associate professor at the Department of General and Theoretical Physics of Sumy State University, where I taught the following disciplines to students:

Quantum Mechanics,
Statistical Physics,
Solid State Physics.

I received a PhD in Physics and Mathematics with a major in Solid State Physics and an academic title of Associate Professor at the Department of Theoretical Physics at Sumy State University, where I was engaged in experimental work investigating the electrophysical properties of thin multilayer metal and semiconductor films.
You can find more information about my work, what I’m writing about, and how to get in contact with me!

title: MD simulation
text:
In the MD simulation procedure there are several limitations, approximations, and parameters that define the accuracy of the obtained results. Among the most important ones are the interatomic interaction potential, simulation time-step, total simulation time, initial conditions, etc. Hence, the first important task in MD simulations is to prepare a model system for further study. In Table Table 1 we collect the main parameters used for simulations of atomic displacements in cascades and for studying defect structure evolution in \(\alpha\)-Zr crystals subjected to irradiation.



Table 1: Simulation parameters









Parameter
Value




Simulation box size, Å
\(163.1 \times 169.498 \times 159.805\)


Number of atoms \(N\)
180 000


Boundary conditions along X, Y, Z axes
periodic, periodic, periodic


Crystal temperature \(T\), K
300, 400, 500


Primary knock-on atom (PKA) energy \(E_{pka}\), keV
2, 6, 10


PKA moving direction
\(\langle 0001 \rangle\), \(\langle 01\overline{1}0 \rangle\)


Thermostat parameter \(\langle \tau \rangle\), ps
0.2


Time step \(\Delta t\), fs
\(0.1 \div 1\)


Total simulation time \(t\), ps
610






In cascade studies it is important that the maximal size of a cascade is smaller than the size of the simulated crystal. Hence, the linear size of the model can be varied with changes in the energy of the bombarding particle, which affects the maximal cascade size. The most important parameters for our MD simulations are the thermostat parameter \(\langle \tau \rangle\) and the simulation time-step \(\Delta t = 0.1 \div 1~\text{fs}\).
The thermostat parameter \(\langle \tau \rangle\) is the mean time over which energy exchange between the system and the thermostat occurs. Since energy in the crystal is transferred from atom to atom, the mean time for energy exchange between two atoms or between an atom and the thermostat is determined by the mean period of atomic oscillations. Thus, the quantity \(\langle \tau \rangle\) corresponds to the mean period of atomic oscillations in the crystal.
The simulation time-step \(\Delta t\) must be much smaller than \(\langle \tau \rangle\) to ensure accurate tracking of atomic positions. In our computations, two values of the simulation time-step were used. The minimal value was chosen as \(\langle \tau \rangle / 2000\), which gives \(\Delta t = 0.1~\text{fs}\). This value was used during cascade development, when a large number of atoms attain high kinetic energies. The maximal time-step was fixed as \(\Delta t = 1~\text{fs}\) (\(\langle \tau \rangle / 200\)) and was used before cascade initiation and after its relaxation.
The value of \(\langle \tau \rangle\) can be obtained within the harmonic approximation. It is known that atoms in a crystal oscillate with frequencies \(\omega\) ranging from zero to the Debye frequency \(\omega_D\). The corresponding distribution function \(g(\omega)\) satisfies the relation [@MD:Kittel]:
\[
g(\omega) = \frac{dz}{d\omega} = \frac{9N\omega^2}{\omega_{\text{max}}^3}.
\tag{1}\]
Rewriting Eq. Equation 1, one obtains the distribution function over the oscillation period:
\[
g(\tau) = \frac{72N\pi^3}{\omega_{\text{max}}^3 \tau^4}.
\]
Taking into account that the total number of elastic waves generated by atoms in the crystal equals \(3N\), the mean period of atomic oscillations can be written as
\[
\langle \tau \rangle =
\int\limits_{2\pi / \omega_{\text{max}}}^{\infty}
\frac{24\pi^3}{\omega_{\text{max}}^3 \tau^3} \, d\tau
= \frac{3\pi}{\omega_{\text{max}}}
= \frac{3\pi\hbar}{kT_D}
\simeq 0.2~\text{ps}.
\tag{2}\]
Using experimental data for the Debye temperature \(T_D = 291~\text{K}\) for pure \(\alpha\)-Zr and the relation \(\omega_D = kT_D / \hbar\), where \(k\) and \(\hbar\) are the Boltzmann and Planck constants, respectively, the mean period of atomic oscillations is found to be \(\langle \tau \rangle = 0.2~\text{ps}\).

Contact potential difference: metal–metal, semiconductor–semiconductor, metal–semiconductor systems.
Distribution of molecules in a centrifuge.
Planetary atmospheres.

title: Statistical Physics
section: Lecture 7. Statistical Foundations of Thermodynamic Laws
text:
Lecture 7. Statistical Foundations of Thermodynamic Laws

Phenomenological and statistical thermodynamics. Internal energy of a macroscopic system.
Quasistatic processes. External parameters. Work and heat from the statistical point of view. First law of thermodynamics.
Entropy in statistical physics. Gibbs theorem. Entropy of nonequilibrium systems. Entropy increase law. Second law of thermodynamics.
Statistical interpretation of the second law of thermodynamics.
Statistical foundation of the third law of thermodynamics.

title: Statistical Physics
text:
Lecture 8. Thermodynamic Potentials

Liquid–vapor phase transition.
Method of thermodynamic potentials. Internal energy, free energy, chemical potential, grand potential.
Calculation of pressure, volume, temperature, entropy. First and second groups of Maxwell relations.
Fundamental thermodynamic equation for systems with variable particle number.
Statistical calculation of thermodynamic potentials.

title: Statistical Physics
section: Lecture 9. Thermodynamic Properties of Classical Ideal Gases
text:
Lecture 9. Thermodynamic Properties of Classical Ideal Gases

Equipartition theorem.
Classical theory of heat capacity of ideal gases.
Quantum theory of heat capacity of ideal gases.

title: Statistical Physics
section: Lecture 10. Interacting Particle Systems. Quantum Statistics
text:
Lecture 10. Interacting Particle Systems. Quantum Statistics

Distribution of particles over quantum states. Grand potential of a quantum state and macroscopic system.
Maxwell–Boltzmann statistics.
Fermi–Dirac statistics.
Bose–Einstein statistics.
Degenerate and non-degenerate systems. Degeneracy temperature.

title: Statistical Physics
section: Lecture 11. Applications of Fermi–Dirac Statistics to Electron Systems
text:
Lecture 11. Applications of Fermi–Dirac Statistics to Electron Systems

Degenerate electron gas. Density of states. Fermi energy and Fermi temperature.
Internal energy of an electron gas at absolute zero and its temperature dependence.
Heat capacity of an electron gas in metals at constant volume.

title: Statistical Physics
section: Lecture 12. Applications of Bose–Einstein Statistics to Boson Systems
text:
Lecture 12. Applications of Bose–Einstein Statistics to Boson Systems

Theory of real gases. Van der Waals equation. Van der Waals isotherms. Critical parameters.
Bose gas:

massive bosons and Bose–Einstein condensation;
photons as massless bosons. Theory of thermal radiation.

title: Statistical Physics
text:
Lecture 13. Fluctuation Theory

Fluctuations. Mean square fluctuations. Gaussian distribution of fluctuations.
Fluctuations of volume, particle number, and density.
Fluctuations of internal energy and temperature.
Electrical fluctuations. Shot noise and Johnson–Nyquist thermal noise.

title: Statistical Physics
text:
Lecture 14. Boltzmann Kinetic Equation

Nonequilibrium states. Nonequilibrium distribution function.
Boltzmann equation as a consequence of the Liouville theorem.
Collision integral.
Relaxation time approximation.
Transport phenomena described by the Boltzmann equation.

title: Statistical Physics
text:
Lecture 15. Transport Phenomena

Mean free path. Effective cross section.
Attenuation of molecular beams in gases.
Viscosity and thermal conductivity of gases.
Self-diffusion in gases.
Rarefied gas phenomena. Effusion.

title: Statistical Physics
section: Lecture 16. Systems with Variable Particle Number. Chemical Potential
text:
Lecture 16. Systems with Variable Particle Number. Chemical Potential

Definition of chemical potential via thermodynamic potentials.
Entropy increase in equilibration processes. Extremal properties of thermodynamic functions.
Thermodynamic inequalities.

title: Statistical Physics
text:
Lecture 17. Theory of Phase Transitions

Phase concept. Phase equilibrium. First-order phase transitions.
Triple point. Superheating and supercooling.
Second-order phase transitions.
Multicomponent systems. Gibbs phase rule.
Chemical equilibrium in homogeneous systems. Law of mass action.

title: Molecular Dynamics and ab initio Modeling in Materials Science
text:
Course Description
This course focuses on modern molecular dynamics (MD) and ab initio simulation methods applied to the investigation of metals and alloys at the atomic scale. Special attention is given to MD algorithms, density functional theory (DFT), and hands-on experience with leading computational packages such as LAMMPS and Quantum ESPRESSO.
Students acquire practical skills in model construction, analysis of diffusion, mechanical and thermodynamic properties of materials, as well as electronic structure calculations. The course is aimed at developing competencies required for advanced scientific research in materials science and solid-state physics.

title: Molecular Dynamics and ab initio Modeling in Materials Science
text:
Course Objective
The objective of the course is to develop systematic theoretical knowledge and practical skills in applying molecular dynamics and ab initio quantum-mechanical methods to study atomic structure, physical properties, and evolutionary processes in metals and alloys.
Special emphasis is placed on the selection and application of modern interatomic potentials, DFT tools, and computational algorithms, as well as on the interpretation of simulation results for solving contemporary problems in solid-state physics and materials science.

title: Molecular Dynamics and ab initio Modeling in Materials Science
text:
Learning Outcomes

Competencies
Upon completion of the course, PhD students will be able to:

Understand fundamental principles of molecular dynamics (MD) and ab initio methods, including density functional theory (DFT).
Select and parameterize interatomic potentials for metals and alloys and assess their validity.
Perform classical MD simulations using LAMMPS.
Conduct DFT calculations using Quantum ESPRESSO.
Apply ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) for modeling atomic motion at finite temperatures.
Integrate MD and DFT results through multiscale and machine-learning approaches.
Critically analyze and interpret simulation results.



Learning Results
Students will be able to:

Explain physical principles underlying MD and ab initio methods.
Justify the choice of interatomic potentials and simulation parameters.
Construct atomic models including defects and surfaces.
Analyze diffusion, mechanical, thermodynamic, and electronic properties.

title: Molecular Dynamics and ab initio Modeling in Materials Science

Course Content

Lectures

Module 1. Introduction and Theoretical Foundations

Introduction to Computational Materials Science History and role of modeling; ab initio, MD, Monte Carlo methods. Hours: 2
Fundamental Atomic-Scale Equations Schrödinger equation; Born–Oppenheimer approximation. Hours: 2
Quantum-Mechanical Calculation Methods DFT, pseudopotentials, exchange–correlation functionals. Hours: 2




Module 2. Interatomic Interactions

Empirical Potentials for Metals EAM, MEAM, Finnis–Sinclair, Gupta potentials. Hours: 2
Construction and Scaling of Potentials Alloy systems and validation strategies. Hours: 2




Module 3. Molecular Dynamics

Fundamentals of Classical Molecular Dynamics Integration algorithms; statistical ensembles. Hours: 2
Implementation of MD in Software Packages LAMMPS workflows and input structures. Hours: 2
Modeling Physical Properties of Metals Elastic constants, diffusion, correlation functions. Hours: 2
Crystal Defects and Their Dynamics Vacancies, dislocations, grain boundaries. Hours: 2




Module 4. Interaction with Environment

Oxidation and Corrosion in MD Models Reactive force fields: ReaxFF, COMB. Hours: 2
Surface Phenomena and Nanostructures Surface energy and clustering. Hours: 2




Module 5. Ab initio Dynamics and Multiphysics

Ab initio Molecular Dynamics (AIMD) Car–Parrinello MD. Hours: 2
Combining DFT and MD QM/MM and machine-learning potentials. Hours: 2




Module 6. Practical Applications

Modeling Structural and Kinetic Processes in Alloys Phase transitions and diffusion. Hours: 2
Modeling Radiation Damage in Materials Displacement cascades. Hours: 2
